chapter.pasuk: The proverbs of Solomon the son of David, king of Israel, [are];
To know wisdom and discipline, to comprehend words of understanding;
To receive the discipline of wisdom, righteousness, justice, and equity;
To give prudence to the simple, knowledge and discretion to the youth.
Let the wise man hear and increase learning. The understanding man shall acquire wise counsels
to understand an allegory and a figure, the words of the wise and their riddles.
The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge; fools despise wisdom and discipline.
Hearken, my son, to the discipline of your father, and do not forsake the instruction of your mother;
for they are a wreath of grace for your head and a necklace for your neck.
My son, if sinners entice you, do not consent;
if they say, "Come with us; let us lie in wait for blood; let us hide for the innocent, without cause;
let us swallow them up alive like the grave, and the whole ones like those who descend into the pit.
We will find all precious possessions; we will fill our houses with plunder.
Cast your lot among us; we will all have one purse"
my son, do not go on the way with them; restrain your foot from their path,
for their feet run to evil, and they hasten to shed blood.
For the net is scattered without cause in the eyes of all winged fowl,
but they lie in wait for their blood; they hide for their lives.
So are the ways of everyone who commits robbery; it will take away the life of its owner.
Wisdoms shout in the street; in the squares she gives forth her voice.
She calls at the head of the noisy streets; she utters her words at the entrances of the gates in the city;
"How long will you naive ones love naivete, and the scoffers covet scoffing, and the fools hate knowledge?
You shall repent because of my reproof; behold! I will pour out my spirit to you; I will let you know my words.
Since I called you and you refused, I stretched out my hand and no one listened,
and you have made nothing of all my advice, and you did not desire my reproof
I, too, will laugh at your calamity, I will scoff when what you fear comes;
when your fear comes like a storm, and your calamity comes like a whirlwind; when trouble and straits come upon you.
Then they will call me, and I will not answer; they shall seek me, and they shall not find me.
Because they hated knowledge, and did not choose the fear of the Lord;
they did not desire my advice, they despised all my reproof-
they will eat of the fruit of their way, and from their counsels they will be sated,
for the backsliding of the naive shall slay them, and the tranquility of the fools shall cause them to perish.
But he who hearkens to me shall dwell confidently and shall be tranquil from the fear of harm."
My son, if you accept my words, and treasure my commandments,
to make your ear attentive to wisdom, [if] you incline your heart to discernment;
for, if you call for understanding [and] raise your voice for discernment,
if you seek it like silver, and hunt for it like treasures,
then you will understand the fear of the Lord, and you will find the knowledge of God.
For the Lord gives wisdom; from His mouth [come] knowledge and discernment.
He lays up sound wisdom for the upright, a shield for those who walk in integrity;
to keep the paths of justice, and watch the way of His pious.
Then you shall understand righteousness, justice, and equity, every good path.
When wisdom comes into your heart, and knowledge shall be pleasant to your soul,
thought shall watch over you; discretion shall guard you,
to save you from an evil way. From a man who speaks perversity;
[from] those who forsake the ways of uprightness, to go on ways of darkness;
[from] those who rejoice to do evil, and delight in the perversity of evil,
who are crooked in their ways and perverse in their paths.
To save you from a strange woman, from a foreign one who makes her words smooth,
who deserts the lord of her youth and forgets the covenant of her God
for her house sinks to death, and her paths [lead] to the dead;
none who go to her return, neither do they achieve the ways of life
in order that you go in the way of the good, and you keep the ways of the righteous.
For the upright shall dwell in the land, and the perfect shall remain therein.
But the wicked shall be cut off from the land, and the treacherous shall be uprooted therefrom.
My son, forget not My instruction, and may your heart keep My commandments;
for they shall add length of days and years of life and peace to you.
Kindness and truth shall not leave you; bind them upon your neck, inscribe them upon the tablet of your heart;
and find favor and good understanding in the sight of God and man.
Trust in the Lord with all your heart and do not rely upon your understanding.
Know Him in all your ways, and He will direct your paths.
Do not be wise in your own sight; fear the Lord and turn away from evil
it shall be healing for your navel and marrow for your bones.
Honor the Lord from your substance and from the first of all your grain,
and your barns shall be filled with plenty, and your vats will overflow with new wine.
My son, despise not the discipline of the Lord, and do not abhor His chastening,
for the Lord chastens the one He loves, as a father placates a son.
Fortunate is the man who has found wisdom and a man who gives forth discernment,
for its commerce is better than the commerce of silver, and its gain [is better] than fine gold;
it is more precious than pearls, and all your desirable things cannot be compared to it.
Length of days is in its right hand; in its left hand are riches and honor.
Its ways are ways of pleasantness, and all its paths are peace.
It is a tree of life for those who grasp it, and those who draw near it are fortunate.
The Lord founded the earth with wisdom, established the heavens with discernment.
With His knowledge the depths were split, and the heavens drip dew.
My son, let them not depart from your eyes; guard sound wisdom and thought,
and they shall be life for your soul, and grace for your neck.
Then you shall go securely on your way, and your foot shall not stumble.
If you lie down, you shall not fear, and when you lie down, your sleep shall be sweet.
Be not afraid of sudden terror, or of the darkness of the wicked when it will come.
For the Lord shall be your trust, and He shall keep your foot from being caught.
Do not withhold good from the one who needs it when you have power in your hand to do it.
Do not say to your fellow, "Go and return, and tomorrow I will give," though you have it with you.
Devise no harm against your fellow, when he dwells securely with you.
Do not quarrel with anyone without cause, if he did you no harm.
Do not envy a man of violence and do not choose any of his ways;
for the perverse is an abomination to the Lord, but His counsel is with the upright.
The curse of the Lord is in the wicked man's house, but He shall bless the dwelling of the righteous.
If [one goes] to the scoffers, he will scoff; but [if he goes] to the humble, he evokes grace.
The wise shall inherit honor, but the fools take disgrace as their portion.
Children, hearken to the discipline of the Father, and listen to know understanding.
For I gave you good teaching; forsake not My instruction.
For I was a son to my father, a tender one and an only one before my mother.
And he instructed me and said to me, "May your heart draw near to my words; keep my commandments and live.
Acquire wisdom, acquire understanding; do not forget, and do not turn away from the words of my mouth.
Do not forsake her, and she will preserve you; love her and she will guard you.
The beginning of wisdom [is to] acquire wisdom, and with all your possession acquire understanding.
Search for her, and she will exalt you; she will honor you when you embrace her.
She will give your head a wreath of grace; she will transmit to you a crown of glory.
Hearken, my son, and take my words, and years of life will increase for you.
In the way of wisdom I instructed you; I led you in the paths of uprightness.
When you walk, your step will not be straitened, and if you run, you will not stumble.
Take fast hold of discipline, do not let it loose; guard it, for it is your life.
You shall not come in the way of the wicked, and do not walk in the way of the evil.
Avoid it, do not pass through it; turn away from it and pass.
For they will not sleep if they do not commit evil, and their sleep will be robbed away if they do not cause stumbling.
For they eat the bread of wickedness, and they drink the wine of violence.
But the way of the righteous is like the light of dawn; it shines ever brighter until the day is perfect.
The way of the wicked is like pitch darkness; they do not know on what they stumble.
My son, hearken to my words; incline your ear to my sayings.
Let them not depart from your eyes; guard them within your heart,
for they are life for those who find them, and for all his flesh a healing.
From every interdict guard your heart, for the issues of life [come] out of it.
Take crooked speech away from yourself, and put devious lips far away from you.
Let your eyes look forward, and let your eyelids look straight ahead of you.
Weigh the path of your feet, and all your ways will be established.
Turn neither right nor left; keep your feet from evil.
My son, hearken to my wisdom; incline your ear to my understanding,
to watch [your] thoughts, and your lips shall guard knowledge.
For the lips of a strange woman drip honey, and her palate is smoother than oil.
But her end is as bitter as wormwood, as sharp as a two-edged sword.
Her feet descend to death; her steps come near the grave.
Lest you weigh the path of life, her paths have wandered off and you shall not know.
And now, children, hearken to me and do not turn away from the sayings of my mouth.
Distance your way from her and do not draw near to the entrance of her house,
lest you give others your glory, and your years to a cruel one;
lest strangers be sated with your strength and your labors be in the house of an alien.
And you shall moan when your end comes, when your flesh and your body are consumed,
and you will say, "How [is it that] I hated discipline, and my heart despised reproof;
and I did not hearken to my instructors, and to my teachers I did not incline my ear?
I was almost in all evil, in the midst of the congregation and the assembly."
Drink water from your own cistern and running water from your own spring.
May your springs spread out rivulets of water in the squares.
You alone shall have them, and strangers shall have nothing with you.
Your fountain shall be blessed, and you shall rejoice with the wife of your youth;
a lovely hind and a graceful mountain goat, her breasts will satisfy you at all times; you shall always be intoxicated with her love.
Now why should you, my son, be intoxicated by a strange woman, and embrace the bosom of an alien one?
For man's ways are opposite the Lord's eyes, and He weighs all his paths.
His iniquities shall trap the wicked man, and he shall be hanged with the ropes of his sin.
He shall die without discipline, and he shall err with his exceeding foolishness.
My son, if you have stood surety for your fellow, have given your hand for a stranger,
you have been trapped by the sayings of your mouth; you have been caught by the sayings of your mouth.
Do this then, my son, and be saved for you have come into your fellow's palm; go, humble yourself and give your fellow superiority.
Give no sleep to your eyes nor slumber to your eyelids.
Save yourself like a deer from the hand and like a bird from the hand of the snare.
Go to the ant, you sluggard; see her ways and become wise,
for she has no chief, overseer, or ruler;
yet she prepares her bread in the summer; she gathers her food in the harvest.
O lazy one, how long will you lie [there]; when will you get up from your sleep?
"A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to lie."
And your poverty shall come like a fast walker and your want as an armed man.
An unscrupulous man, a man of violence, walks with a crooked mouth;
he winks with his eyes, shuffles with his feet, points with his fingers.
Contrariness is in his heart; he plots evil at all times; he incites quarrels.
Therefore, calamity shall come suddenly; he shall suddenly be broken beyond repair.
There are six things that the Lord hates, and the seventh is an abomination of His soul;
Haughty eyes, a lying tongue, and hands that shed innocent blood;
a heart that thinks thoughts of violence; feet that hasten to run to evil;
[one who] speaks lies with false testimony and incites quarrels among brothers.
My son, keep the commands of your father, and do not forsake the instruction of your mother.
Bind them always upon your heart, tie them upon your neck.
When you walk, it shall lead you; when you lie down, it shall guard you, and when you awaken, it shall speak for you.
For a commandment is a candle, and the Torah is light, and disciplining rebukes are the way of life;
to guard you from an evil woman, from the smoothness of the alien tongue.
Do not covet her beauty in your heart, and do not let her captivate you with her eyelids.
Because a man is brought to a loaf of bread for a harlot, and a married woman will hunt a precious soul.
Can a man rake embers with his skirt without burning his clothes?
Or can a man walk on live coals without scorching his feet?
So is he who goes in to his neighbor's wife; no one who touches her will go unpunished.
They will not despise a thief if he steals to sate his appetite, for he is hungry.
And if he is found, he will pay sevenfold; he must give all he owns.
One who commits adultery with a woman is devoid of sense; one who would destroy his soul-he will do it.
He will find wounds and disgrace, and his reproach shall not be erased
for jealousy [shall arouse] the husband's wrath, and he will not have pity on the day of vengeance.
He will not have regard for any ransom, neither will he consent though you give him many bribes.
My son, keep my sayings, and hide my commandments with you.
Keep my commandments and live, and my instruction like the apple of your eyes.
Bind them on your fingers; inscribe them on the tablet of your heart.
Say to wisdom, "You are my sister," and you shall call understanding a kinsman;
to guard you from a strange woman, from an alien woman who talks smoothly.
For from the window of my house, through my lattice I gazed,
and I saw among the simple-I discerned among the youths-a lad devoid of sense,
crossing the street next to her corner, and he walks on the way to her house.
In the twilight, in the evening of the day, in the pitch darkness of the night.
And behold a woman [was coming] toward him, the nakedness of a harlot with her heart besieged.
She is bustling and rebellious; her feet do not dwell in her house.
Sometimes [she is] in the street, sometimes in the squares, and she lurks at every corner.
She takes hold of him and kisses him; brazenly she says to him,
"I had to bring peace-offerings; today I paid my vows.
Therefore, I have come out toward you to look for you, and I have found you.
I have bedecked my couch with covers, with superior braided work of Egypt.
I fanned my couch with myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.
Come, let us take our fill of lovemaking until morning; let us enjoy ourselves with amorous embraces.
For the man is not at home; he has gone on a long journey.
He has taken the bag of money with him; on the appointed day he will come home."
She swayed him with all her talk; with the smooth talk of her lips she entices him.
He follows her immediately-as an ox goes to the slaughter, and as a viper to the chastisement of a fool
until an arrow splits his liver, as a bird hastens to a snare, and he does not know that it is at the cost of his life.
And now, children, hearken to me, and listen to the sayings of my mouth.
Let your heart not veer off into her ways; stray not in her paths.
For many are the dead that she has felled, and numerous are all her victims.
The ways of the grave are to her house, descending to the chambers of death.
Will not wisdom call out, and understanding give forth its voice?
At the top of the heights upon the road; at the crossroads she stands.
Beside the gates, at the entrance of the roof, at the entrance of the portals she cries,
"To you, O men, I call, and my voice [is] to the children of man.
O simpletons, understand cunning, and you fools, give understanding to your heart.
Hearken for I will speak noble things, and the opening of my lips shall be right things.
For my palate shall utter truth, and wickedness is an abomination of my lips.
All the sayings of my lips are with righteousness; there is nothing twisted or crooked in them.
They are all true to the understanding one, and straight to those who find knowledge.
Take my discipline and not silver; knowledge is chosen above gold.
For wisdom is better than pearls; all desirable things cannot be compared to it.
I am wisdom; I dwelt [beside] cunning, and the knowledge of devices I will find.
Fear of the Lord is to hate evil, haughtiness, pride, the way of evil, and a perverse mouth; [these] I hate.
I have counsel and sound wisdom; I am understanding; I have might.
Kings reign with me, and rulers legislate righteousness.
Through me princes govern, and nobles, yea, all judges of righteousness.
I will love those who love me, and those who seek me eagerly will find me.
Riches and honor are with me, powerful wealth and charity.
My fruit is better than gold-yea than fine gold- and my produce [is better] than choice silver.
In the way of righteousness I will go, in the midst of the paths of justice.
There is substance to give inheritance to those who love me, and I will fill their treasuries.
The Lord acquired me at the beginning of His way, before His works of old.
From the distant past I was enthroned, from the beginning, of those that preceded the earth.
I was created when there were yet no deeps, when there were no fountains replete with water.
I was created before the mountains were sunk, before the hills;
when He had not yet made the land and the outsides and the beginning of the dust of the earth.
When He established the heavens, there I was, when He drew a circle over the face of the deep;
when He made the skies above firm, when He strengthened the fountains of the deep;
when He gave the sea its boundary, and the water shall not transgress His command, when He established the foundations of the earth
I was a nursling beside Him, and I was [His] delight every day, playing before Him at all times;
playing in the habitable world of His earth, and [having] my delights with the children of man.
And now, my children, hearken to me, and fortunate are those who observe my ways.
Hearken to discipline and become wise, and do not put it to naught.
Fortunate is the man who listens to me to watch by my doors day by day, to watch the doorposts of my entrances.
For he who has found me has found life, and he has obtained favor from the Lord.
But he who sins against me robs his soul; all who hate me, love death."
Wisdom has built her house; she has hewn her seven pillars.
She has prepared her meat; she has mingled her wine; she has even set her table.
She has sent her maidens, she calls on the wings of the heights of the city,
"Whoever is simple, let him turn in here." To the one devoid of sense, she says to him,
"Come, partake of my bread and drink of the wine I have mingled.
Leave, you simpletons, and live, and step in the way of understanding."
He who chastens a scorner takes disgrace for himself, and he who reproves a wicked man, that is his blemish.
Reprove not a scorner lest he hate you; reprove a wise man and he will love you.
Give a wise man, and he will become yet wiser; teach a righteous man, and he will increase in learning.
The beginning of wisdom is the fear of the Lord, and the knowledge of the holy ones is understanding.
For with me shall your days increase, and they will add to you years of life.
If you have become wise, you have become wise for yourself, and if you scorn, you will bear it alone.
The woman of folly is turbulent; [she is] simple and knows nothing.
She sits at the entrance of her house on a chair on the heights of the city,
to call the passersby, who are going straight on their ways,
"Whoever is simple, let him turn in here, and whoever is devoid of sense," and she says to him,
"Stolen water is sweet, and bread eaten in secret is pleasant."
But he does not know that shades are there; her guests are in the depths of the grave.
Proverbs of Solomon: A wise son makes his father happy, but a foolish son is the grief of his mother.
Treasures of wickedness will not avail, but charity will save from death.
The Lord will not starve the soul of the righteous, but the destruction [wrought by] the wicked will cast [them] down.
A poor man makes a deceitful scale, and the hand of those who make true decisions will make [them] rich.
An intelligent son gathers in the summer, whereas an embarrassing son sleeps soundly during the harvest.
Blessings [shall come] upon the head of a righteous man, but violence shall cover the mouth of the wicked.
The mention of a righteous man is for a blessing, but the name of the wicked shall rot.
The wise-hearted takes commandments, but he who talks foolishly will weary.
He who walks in innocence walks securely, but he who perverts his ways will be broken.
He who winks his eye causes grief, and he who talks foolishly will weary.
The mouth of the righteous is a fountain of life, but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.
Hatred arouses quarrels, but love covers all transgressions.
Wisdom is found in the lips of the understanding, but a rod is for the body of one devoid of sense.
Wise men store up knowledge, but the mouth of a fool [causes] destruction to come near.
The wealth of the rich is the city of his strength; the destruction of the poor is their poverty.
The act of the righteous is for life; what the wicked bring in is for sin.
The way to life is if one keeps discipline, but he who forsakes reproof misleads.
He who covers up hatred has false lips, and he who spreads slander is a fool.
In a multitude of words, transgression will not be avoided, and he who holds back his lips is wise.
The tongue of the righteous is choice silver; the heart of the wicked is worth little.
The lips of the righteous will feed many, but the fools will die for lack of sense.
The blessing of the Lord will bring riches, and toil will add nothing to it.
As it is sport for a fool to carry out a sinful plot, [so is] wisdom for a man of understanding.
The dread of a wicked man-that will befall him, but the desire of the righteous He will grant.
When the whirlwind passes, the wicked man is no more, but the righteous is the foundation of the world.
Like vinegar to the teeth and like smoke to the eyes, so is the sluggard to those who send him.
Fear of the Lord will add days, but the years of the wicked will be shortened.
The expectation of the righteous [will result in] joy, but the hope of the wicked shall be lost.
The way of the Lord is a stronghold for the innocent, but ruin for those who work iniquity.
The righteous will not collapse forever, but the wicked shall not dwell in the land.
The mouth of a righteous man speaks wisdom, but a perverse tongue shall be cut off.
The lips of a righteous man know how to please, but the mouth of the wicked [knows] how to distort.
Deceitful scales are an abomination of the Lord, but a perfect weight is His will.
When willful wickedness comes, then comes disgrace, but with the modest is wisdom.
The innocence of the upright leads them, but the distortion of the treacherous robs them.
Riches will not avail on the day of wrath, but charity will save from death.
The righteousness of the innocent will straighten his way, but the wicked will fall in his wickedness.
The righteousness of the upright will save them, but in the destruction, the treacherous will be caught.
When a wicked man dies, hope is lost, and the expectation of his children is lost.
A righteous man is extricated from trouble, and a wicked man comes in his stead.
With his mouth, the flatterer destroys his neighbor; but with knowledge, righteous men are extricated.
When it goes well with the righteous, the city rejoices, and when the wicked perish, there is song.
With the blessing of the upright, the ceiling is raised, but with the mouth of the wicked it is demolished.
He who despises his neighbor is devoid of sense, but a man of understanding is silent.
He who reveals secrets is a talebearer, but one who is of faithful spirit conceals a matter.
Without strategy the people falls, but with many counselors there is victory.
He who gives surety for a stranger will be broken by it, but he who hates hand-claspers [for surety] is secure.
A charming woman draws near to honor, but strong men draw near to riches.
A kind man does himself good, but a cruel one troubles his own flesh.
A wicked man earns illusory wages, but he who sows charity [receives] a true reward.
The truth of charity is for life, but one who pursues evil [leads] to his death.
Those who are perverse in heart are an abomination of the Lord, but He desires those who are sincere in their way.
From hand to hand the evil will not be cleansed, but the seed of the righteous escapes.
[As] a gold ring in a swine's snout, is a beautiful woman from whom sense has departed.
The desire of the righteous is only good; the hope of the wicked is wrath.
There is one who scatters and yet is given more, and one who withholds from [giving] what is proper, only for a loss.
A generous person will become rich, and he who sates [others] shall himself become sated as well.
He who keeps back grain-the nation will curse him, but a blessing will be bestowed on the head of him who sells grain.
He who desires good seeks acceptance, but he who seeks evil, it will befall him.
He who relies on his wealth will fall, but the righteous will flourish like a leaf.
He who inherits the wind will trouble his household; the fool is a slave to the wisehearted.
The fruit of a righteous man is the tree of life, and the wise man acquires souls.
Behold! The righteous man will be requited on earth; surely a wicked man and a sinner.
He who loves discipline loves knowledge, but he who hates reproof is brutish.
A good man will obtain favor of the Lord, but a man of evil devices will condemn.
A man will not be established with wickedness; but the root of the righteous will not be shaken loose.
A virtuous woman is the crown of her husband, but an embarrassing one is like rot in his bones.
The thoughts of the righteous are justice; the devices of the wicked are deceit.
The words of the wicked are to lurk for blood, but the mouth of the upright will save them.
The wicked will be overthrown and they are no more, but the house of the righteous will stand.
According to his intelligence a man is praised, but he whose heart has turned away will be despised.
Better is he who is lightly esteemed but is a slave to himself than one who is honored but lacks bread.
A righteous man has regard for the desire of his beast, but the mercy of the wicked is cruel.
He who tills his soil will be sated with bread, but he who pursues empty things is devoid of sense.
The wicked man yearns for the prey of evil men, but the root of the righteous yields [fruit].
Because of the trangression of the lips there is an evil snare, but the righteous comes out of trouble.
From the fruit of a man's mouth he will be sated with good, and He will return the reward of a man's hands to him.
A fool's way is straight in his eyes, but he who listens to advice is a wise man.
A fool's anger is known within the day, but a clever man conceals his shame.
He who speaks the truth will testify justly, but a deceitful person will be a false witness.
There is one who speaks like the jabs of a sword, but the tongue of the wise brings healing.
A true tongue will be established forever, but a lying tongue, just for a moment.
There is deceit in the heart of those who plot evil, but for the counselors of peace there is joy.
No wrong shall be caused for the righteous, but the wicked are full of evil.
False lips are an abomination of the Lord, but those who work faithfully are His delight.
A cunning man conceals knowledge, but the heart of the fools calls out foolishness.
The hand of the diligent will rule, but deceit will lead to payment of tribute.
If there is concern in a man's heart, let him cast it down, and a good word will make it cheerful.
The righteous is more generous than his neighbor, and the way of the wicked will lead them astray.
He will not roast his prey of deceit, but the wealth of an honest man is precious.
In the road of charity is life, and [on] the way of its path there is no death.
A wise son [seeks] his father's discipline, but a scorner does not listen to rebuke.
From the fruit of a man's mouth he will eat good, but the desire of the treacherous is violence.
He who watches his mouth guards his soul; for one who opens his lips wide there is ruin.
The soul of the lazy man desires but has nothing, but the soul of the diligent shall be sated.
The righteous man hates a false word, but the wicked disgraces and embarrasses.
Charity guards him who is steadfast in his way, but wickedness brings ruin upon the sinner.
There is one who feigns riches but has nothing; one who feigns poverty but has great wealth.
The ransom of a man's soul is his wealth, as long as the poor man has not heard a rebuke.
The light of the righteous will rejoice, but the candle of the wicked will ebb away.
Only with wickedness does one cause quarrels, but there is wisdom with those who take counsel.
Wealth gotten by vanity shall be diminished, but he who gathers by hand will increase.
Hope deferred makes the heart sick, but a desire fulfilled is a tree of life.
He who despises a thing will be pledged to it, but he who reveres a commandment will be rewarded.
The instruction of a wise man is a spring of life, to turn away from the snares of death.
Good sense will grant favor, but the way of the treacherous is harsh.
Every cunning man acts with forethought, but a fool exposes [his] stupidity.
A wicked messenger falls into evil, but a faithful emissary brings healing.
Poverty and disgrace befall him who spurns discipline, but he who keeps reproof will be honored.
A desire fulfilled pleases the soul, but the abomination of the fools is to turn away from evil.
He who goes with the wise will become wise, but he who befriends the fools will be broken.
Evil will pursue the sinners but the righteous He will pay a good [reward].
A good man will leave an inheritance for his sons' sons, but the wealth of a sinner is laid away for the righteous.
An abundance of food is the result of the plowing of the poor, and some perish because of lack of propriety.
He who holds back his rod hates his son, but he who loves him disciplines him early.
A righteous man eats to sate his appetite, but the stomach of the wicked shall feel want.
The wisest of women-each one built her house, but a foolish one tears it down with her hands.
He who fears the Lord goes in his uprightness, but he whose ways are perverse despises Him.
In a fool's mouth is a staff of haughtiness but the lips of the wise guard them.
Without oxen the manger is empty, but an abundance comes by the strength of an ox.
A faithful witness does not lie, but he who speaks lies is a false witness.
The scorner sought wisdom, but it is not there; but knowledge for the understanding one is easy.
Go far away from a foolish man or you will not know lips of knowledge.
The wisdom of a cunning man is to understand his way, but the folly of the fools is deceit.
Amends for guilt plead for the fools, but there is good will among the upright.
One's heart knows the bitterness of his soul, and in his joy no stranger shall mingle.
The house of the wicked shall be destroyed, but the tent of the righteous shall flourish.
There is a way that seems right to a man, but its end is ways of death.
Even with laughter, the heart aches, and its end is that joy turns to sorrow.
The one with an impure heart shall have his fill from his ways, and above him is a good man.
A fool believes everything, but a cunning man understands his steps.
A wise man fears and turns away from evil, but a fool passes vigorously and slips.
A quick-tempered man acts foolishly, and a man of sinful plots is hated.
Fools inherit folly, but the cunning make knowledge a crown.
The evil bend down before the good, and the wicked on the gates of a righteous man.
The poor man is hated even by his friend, but the friends of the rich are many.
He who despises his friend is a sinner, but he who favors the humble-fortunate is he.
Will they who plan evil not go astray? But kindness and truth come to those who plan good.
In every toil there will be gain, but a word of the lips is only for loss.
The crown of the wise is their wealth; the folly of the foolish is folly.
A true witness saves lives, but he who speaks lies is [a man of] deceit.
In the fear of the Lord is a strong promise, and he will be a shelter for his sons.
The fear of the Lord is a spring of life, to turn away from the snares of death.
The King's glory is in a multitude of people, but the ruin of His Princedom is in lack of people.
He who is slow to anger is of great understanding, but he who is quick-tempered selects folly.
A healing heart is the life of the flesh, but anger is the rot of the bones.
He who oppresses a poor man blasphemes his Maker, but he who favors a poor man honors Him.
A wicked man is thrust down with his evil, but a righteous man is confident in his death.
Wisdom rests in the heart of an understanding man, but in the midst of the fools it is known.
Charity will elevate a nation, but the kindness of the kingdoms is sin.
The king's good will is to an intelligent servant, but his wrath will be upon a shameful one.
A gentle reply turns away wrath, but a distressing word stirs up anger.
The tongue of the wise enhances knowledge, but the mouth of the fools pours out folly.
The eyes of the Lord are everywhere, viewing the evil and the good.
A healing tongue is a tree of life, but if there is perverseness in it, it causes destruction by wind.
A fool despises the discipline of his father, but he who keeps reproof will become cunning.
The house of a righteous man possesses great strength, but it becomes ruined with the bringing of the wicked man.
The lips of the wise crown knowledge, but the heart of the fools is not so.
The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination of the Lord, but the prayer of the upright is His will.
The way of a wicked man is an abomination of the Lord, but He loves him who pursues righteousness.
Harsh discipline will come to him who forsakes the way; he who hates reproof shall die.
The grave and Destruction are opposite the Lord- surely people's hearts.
A scorner does not like being reproved; he does not go to the wise.
A merry heart makes a cheerful face, but by sadness of heart comes a breaking spirit.
The heart of an understanding person seeks knowledge, but the mouth of fools befriends folly.
All the days of a poor man are wretched, but he who has a cheerful heart always has a feast.
Better a little with the fear of the Lord, than a great treasury and turmoil with it.
Better a repast of herbs where there is love, than a fattened ox where there is hatred.
A man of wrath stirs up quarrels, but he who is slow to anger abates strife.
The way of a lazy man is like a hedge of thorns, but the path of the upright is even.
A wise son makes his father happy, but a foolish person despises his mother.
Folly is joy to one devoid of sense, but a man of understanding walks straight.
Plans are foiled for lack of counsel, but they are established through many advisers.
A man has joy with the response of his mouth; and how good is a word in time!
The path of life is above the intelligent person, in order that he turn away from the grave below.
The Lord will uproot the house of the haughty, but He will establish the boundary of the widow.
The thoughts of an evil person are an abomination of the Lord, but pleasant words are pure.
He who is greedy of gain troubles his own house, but he who hates gifts will live.
The heart of a righteous man thinks to answer, but the mouth of the wicked pours out evils.
The Lord is far from the wicked, but He listens to the prayer of the righteous.
The light of the eyes makes the heart happy; good news fattens the bone.
The ear that listens to reproof of life shall lodge among the wise.
He who rejects discipline despises his life, but he who hearkens to reproof acquires sense.
The fear of the Lord is the discipline of wisdom, and before honor there is humility.
The preparations of the heart are man's, but the answer of the tongue is from the Lord.
All ways of man are pure in his eyes, but the Lord counts the spirits.
Commit your affairs to the Lord, and your plans will be established.
The Lord made everything for His praise-even the wicked man for the day of evil.
Everyone of haughty heart is an abomination of the Lord; hand to hand he will not go unpunished.
With loving-kindness and truth will iniquity be expiated, and through fear of the Lord turn away from evil.
When the Lord accepts a person's ways, He will cause even his enemies to make peace with him.
Better a little with righteousness than great revenues with injustice.
A man's heart plans his way, but the Lord prepares his step.
There is magic on a king's lips; his mouth commits no treachery in judgment.
The balance and scales of justice are the Lord's; all the weights in the bag are His work.
It is an abomination to kings to commit wickedness, for with righteousness the throne is established.
Righteous lips are the delight of kings, and he loves the one who speaks honestly.
The king's wrath is [like] messengers of death, but a wise man will pacify it.
In the light of the King's countenance is life, and His delight is like a cloud of the late rain.
How much better is it to acquire wisdom than gold! And to acquire understanding is preferable to silver.
The highway of the upright is to turn away from evil; he who guards his soul watches his way.
Before destruction comes pride, and before stumbling [comes] a haughty spirit.
It is better to be of humble spirit with the lowly than to divide the spoils with the haughty.
He who considers a matter will find good, and he who trusts in the Lord is fortunate.
The wise-hearted shall be called understanding; and the sweetness of speech increases learning.
Intelligence is a fountain of life to one who has it, but the chastisement of the fools is folly.
The heart of a wise man give his mouth intelligence and adds learning to his lips.
Pleasant words are as a honeycomb, sweet to the soul and healing to the bones.
There is a way [that is] straight in a man's view, but its end is ways of death.
The soul of a laborer labors for him, when his mouth forces him.
An ungodly man digs up evil, and on his lips is a kind of searing fire.
A perverse man incites quarrel, and a grumbler alienates the Lord.
A man of violence entices his neighbor and leads him on a way that is not good.
He winks his eyes to think perverse thoughts; he purses his lips, bringing evil to pass.
A hoary head is a crown of glory; it will be found in the way of righteousness.
One who is slow to anger is better than a mighty man, and one who rules over his spirit [is better] than one who conquers a city.
The lot is cast in the lap, but all his judgment is from the Lord.
Better a piece of dry bread and tranquility with it, than a house full of sacrifices of strife.
An intelligent slave will rule over a disgraceful son, and among the brothers he will divide the inheritance.
A refining pot is for silver, and a furnace is for gold, but the Lord tests the hearts.
An evildoer hearkens to a language of violence; a liar lends an ear to destructive language.
He who mocks a poor man blasphemes his Maker; he who rejoices at a misfortune will not go unpunished.
Children's children are the crown of the aged, and the glory of the children is their fathers.
Proud words do not befit a vile person, surely not lying speech a generous one.
A bribe is a precious stone in the eyes of the one who has it; wherever he turns, he prospers.
He who conceals transgression seeks love, but he who harps on a matter alienates the Lord.
The humility caused by the rebuke of an understanding person [is more effective] than a hundred blows to a fool.
He who is only rebellious seeks evil, and a cruel angel shall be sent against him.
May a bereaving bear encounter a person rather than a fool with his folly.
He who repays evil for good-evil will not depart from his house.
The beginning of strife is like letting out water, and before you are exposed, abandon the quarrel.
He who vindicates the wicked and condemns the righteous-both are an abomination to the Lord.
Why is there a price in the fool's hand to buy wisdom, when the heart is not here?
At all times, love a friend, for he is born a brother for adversity.
A person without sense clasps hands; he becomes surety before his neighbor.
He who delights in transgression delights in quarrels; he who speaks haughtily seeks disaster.
He who is of a perverse heart will find no good, and he who has a hypocritical tongue will fall into evil.
He who begets a fool, does so to his sorrow; neither will the father of a vile man rejoice.
A happy heart enhances one's brilliance, and a broken spirit dries the bones.
He will take a bribe from a wicked man's bosom, to pervert the roads of justice.
Wisdom is directly in front of an understanding man, but the eyes of a fool are at the end of the earth.
A foolish son causes anger to his father, and bitterness to her who bore him.
To punish also the righteous man is not good-to strike the generous who possess uprightness.
He who has knowledge keeps back his words; he whose breath is dear is a man of understanding.
He who silences even a fool is considered a wise man; one who shuts his lips, a man of understanding.
He who is separated seeks lust; in all sound wisdom, he is exposed.
A fool does not delight in understanding, but in revealing his heart.
When a wicked man comes, there also comes contempt, and with disdain, provocation.
The words of a man's mouth are like deep water; the wellspring of wisdom is a flowing stream.
It is not good to be partial to the wicked, to subvert the righteous in judgment.
The lips of a fool will enter a quarrel, and his mouth calls out for blows.
A fool's mouth is his ruin, and his lips are a snare for himself.
The words of a grumbler are like blows, and they descend into the inmost parts.
Even one who is slack in his work is akin to the destroyer.
The name of the Lord is a tower of strength; the righteous runs into it and is strengthened.
A rich man's wealth is his strong city, and like a strong wall in his chamber.
Before ruin, a man's heart becomes haughty, but before honor there is humility.
He who answers a word before he understands-it is foolishness for him and an embarrassment.
A man's spirit will sustain his illness, but a broken spirit-who will bear it?
An understanding heart will acquire knowledge, and the ear of the wise will seek knowledge.
A man's gift will make room for him, and it will lead him before the great.
He who pleads his case first seems just, but his neighbor comes and searches him out.
The lot causes quarrels to cease, and it separates contentious people.
A rebellious brother [is deprived] of a strong city, and the quarrels are like the bolt of a castle.
With the fruit of his mouth does a man's stomach become sated; with the produce of his lips he is sated.
Death and life are in the hand of the tongue, and those who love it will eat its produce.
He who has found a wife has found good, and has obtained favor from the Lord.
A poor man speaks with supplications, but a rich man replies with impudence.
A man acquires friends with whom to associate, and there is a friend who sticks closer than a brother.
Better a poor man who walks innocently than one with perverse lips, who is a fool.
It is also not good that a soul be without knowledge, and he who hastens with his feet sins.
A man's folly perverts his way, but his heart is wroth with the Lord.
Wealth adds many friends, but a poor man is separated from his friend.
A false witness will not go unpunished, and one who speaks lies will not escape.
The great will beg the favor of a generous man, and everyone is a friend to a man who gives gifts.
All the kinsmen of a poor man hate him; surely his friends distance themselves from him; he pursues statements that are fit for him.
He who acquires sense loves his soul; he who guards understanding will eventually find good.
A false witness will not go unpunished, and one who speaks lies will perish.
Pleasure does not befit a fool, much less a slave to rule over princes.
It is good sense for a man to be slow to anger, and it is his glory to pass over a transgression.
The King's fury is like a lion's roar, but His good will is like dew upon the grass.
A foolish son is the calamity of his father, and the quarrels of a wife are [like] a constant dripping.
A house and wealth are the heritage of the fathers, but an intelligent wife is from the Lord.
Laziness causes one to fall into a deep sleep, and a deceitful soul shall suffer hunger.
He who keeps a commandment keeps his soul; he who despises his ways will die.
He who is gracious to a poor man lends to the Lord, and He will repay him his reward.
Chastise your son for there is hope, but do not set your heart on his destruction.
A hot-tempered man incurs punishment, but if you save you will yet increase.
Hearken to advice and accept discipline, in order that you may be wise in your later years.
There are many thoughts in a man's heart, but God's plan-that shall stand.
The attraction to a man is his kindness, and a poor man is better than a liar.
Fear of the Lord is for life, and he will rest satisfied, not to be visited by evil.
A lazy man hid his hand in a kettle; he will not return it even to his mouth.
Beat a scorner, and a simple man will gain cunning; reprove a man of understanding, and he will understand knowledge.
A son who causes shame and disgrace robs his father, puts his mother to flight.
My son, cease to stray from words of knowledge to hear discipline.
A godless witness testifies judgment, but violence will devour the mouth of the wicked.
Punishments are prepared for the scorners and blows for the body of fools.
The [imbiber of] wine is a scorner; he roars, "Strong drink!" And whoever strays with it will not become wise.
Fear of a king is like a lion's roar; he who provokes him forfeits his life.
It is honor for a man to refrain from quarreling, and every fool will be exposed.
Because of the winter, a lazy man does not plow; he will seek in harvest, and there will be nothing.
Counsel in man's heart is like deep water, but a man of understanding will draw it out.
Many people call upon the man who promises them kindness, but who can find a trustworthy man?
He who walks innocently is righteous; fortunate are his sons after him.
A king sits upon a throne of judgment; all evil is spread out before him.
Who will say, "I have cleansed my heart; I have become purified of my sin"?
Diverse weights and diverse measures-even both are an abomination of the Lord.
Even a child can disguise himself with his deeds, if his deed is pure or upright.
The hearing ear and the seeing eye, the Lord has made even both of them.
Do not love sleep lest you become poor, open your eyes and be sated with bread.
"It is bad, it is bad, " says the buyer, but when he goes away, then he boasts.
There is gold and many pearls, but lips of knowledge are like a precious vessel.
Take his garment because he stood surety for a stranger, and hold him in pledge for an alien woman.
Bread of falsehood is sweet to a man, but afterwards his mouth will be filled with gravel.
Plans with counsel will be established, and with strategies wage war.
You shall not mingle with one who divulges secrets, one who gossips, or with one who entices with his lips.
If one curses his father and mother, his lamp will flicker in the blackest darkness.
An inheritance may be acquired hastily in the beginning, but its end will not be blessed.
Do not say, "I will repay evil." Hope to the Lord, and He will save you.
Diverse weights are an abomination of the Lord, and deceptive scales are not good.
A man's steps are from the Lord, for man understands nothing of his way.
When a man is trapped he impairs his sanctity, and he must seek vows.
The Wise King scatters the wicked, and turns the wheel over them.
Man's soul is the Lord's lamp, which searches out all the innermost parts.
Kindness and truth preserve the king, and he supports his throne with kindness.
The glory of young men is their strength, and the beauty of elders is a hoary head.
Contusions and wounds come for outpouring in evil, and plagues in the innermost parts.
A king's heart is like rivulets of water in the Lord's hand; wherever He wishes, He turns it.
Man's every way is straight in his own eyes, but the Lord counts the hearts.
Performing charity and justice is preferred by God to a sacrifice.
Haughty eyes and unlimited lust-the tillage of the wicked is sin.
The plans of a diligent man lead only to advantage, whereas every hasty one hurries only to want.
Gathering treasures with a lying tongue is like a driven vapor; they seek death.
The plunder of the wicked frightens them, for they have refused to perform justice.
A man's way is changeable and he is strange, but as for a pure one-his deed is right.
It is better to sit on the corner of a roof than with a quarrelsome wife and the house of a friend.
The soul of a wicked man desires evil; his neighbor finds no favor in his eyes.
When a scorner is punished, a fool gains wisdom, but when a wise man is instructed, he gains knowledge.
The Righteous One considers the house of the wicked, overthrowing the wicked to their ruin.
He who stops up his ear from the cry of a poor man-he, too, will cry out and not be answered.
A gift in secret will appease wrath, and a bribe in the pocket [will even appease] strong wrath.
It is a joy for a righteous man to do judgment, and a ruin for those who commit violence.
A man who strays from the way of understanding will rest in the congregation of the shades.
He who loves joy shall be a poor man; he who loves wine and oil shall not become rich.
A wicked man shall be ransom for a righteous man, and a treacherous one instead of the upright.
It is better to dwell in a desert land than [with] a quarrelsome and vexatious wife.
Precious treasure and oil are in the dwelling of the wise man, but man's foolishness will swallow it up.
He who pursues charity and kindness will find life, charity, and honor.
A wise man ascended to a city of mighty men and brought down the stronghold in which it trusts.
He who watches his mouth and his tongue guards his soul from troubles.
A malevolent, haughty man-scorner is his name; he acts with malevolent anger.
The desire of a lazy man will bring about his death, for his hands refuse to labor.
All day he covets greedily, but the righteous man gives and does not spare.
The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination, how much more if he brings it with plans of wickedness!
A false witness will perish, but an obedient man may speak forever.
A wicked man shows his brazenness in his anger, but an upright man-he will understand his way.
There is neither wisdom nor understanding nor counsel against the Lord.
A steed is prepared for a day of battle, but the victory is the Lord's.
A name is chosen above great wealth; good favor over silver and gold.
A rich man and a poor man were visited upon; the Lord is the Maker of them all.
A cunning man saw harm and hid, but fools transgressed and were punished.
In the wake of humility comes fear of the Lord, riches, honor, and life.
Troops [and] snares are in the way of the perverse; he who preserves his soul will distance himself from them.
Train a child according to his way; even when he grows old, he will not turn away from it.
A rich man will rule over the poor, and a borrower is a slave to a lender.
He who sows injustice will reap violence, and the rod of his wrath will fail.
He who has a generous eye will be blessed, for he gave of his bread to the poor.
Banish a scorner, and quarrel will depart, and litigation and disgrace will cease.
He who loves one pure of heart with charm on his lips-the King is his friend.
The eyes of the Lord preserve knowledge and He will frustrate the words of a treacherous man.
The lazy man says, "There is a lion outside; I will be murdered in the middle of the streets."
The mouth of strange women is [like] a deep pit; the one abhorred by the Lord will fall therein.
Foolishness is bound in a child's heart; the rod of discipline will drive it far from him.
He who exploits a poor man to increase for himself will give to a rich man only to want.
Incline your ear and hearken to the words of the wise, and put your heart to my knowledge,
for it is pleasant that you guard them in your innards; they will be established together on your lips.
That your trust shall be in the Lord, I have made known to you this day, even you.
Have I not written to you thirds with counsels and knowledge,
to make known to you the certainty of the true words, to respond with words of truth to those who send you?
Do not rob a poor man because he is poor, and do not crush the poor man in the gate.
For the Lord will plead their cause and rob those who rob them, of life.
Do not befriend a quick-tempered person, neither shall you go with a wrathful man;
lest you learn his ways and take a snare for your soul.
Do not be one of those who give their hands, who stand surety for debts.
If you do not have what to pay, why should he take your bed from under you?
Do not remove an ancient boundary that your forefathers set.
Have you seen a man quick in his work? He will stand before kings; he will not stand before poor men.
If you sit down to dine with a ruler, you should understand well who is in front of you,
and you shall put a knife into your jaw if you are a man with a hearty appetite.
Do not desire his delicacies, for it is bread of lies.
Do not weary yourself to grow rich; cease from your own understanding.
Should you blink your eyes at it, it is not here; for it will make wings for itself, like the eagle, and it will fly toward the heavens.
Do not dine upon the bread of a stingy person and do not desire his delicacies;
for it is as though it poured gall into his friend, so is he. He will tell you to eat and drink, but his heart is not with you.
You will vomit out your morsel that you ate, and you will lose your sweet words.
Do not speak into the ears of a fool, for he will despise the sense of your words.
Do not remove an ancient boundary, and do not enter the fields of the orphans-
for their Redeemer is mighty; He will plead their cause with you.
Bring your heart to discipline and your ears to words of knowledge.
Do not withhold discipline from a child; when you strike him with a rod, he will not die.
You shall strike him with a rod, and you will save his soul from the grave.
My son, if your heart has grown wise, my heart too will rejoice.
And my reins shall rejoice when your lips speak right things.
Let your heart not envy the sinners, but fear of the Lord all day-
for because of this, there is a future, and your hope will not be cut off.
Hear you, my son, and grow wise, and walk in the way of your heart.
Do not be among wine-guzzlers, among gluttonous eaters of meat for themselves,
for the guzzler and the glutton will become impoverished, and slumber will clothe [you] with tatters.
Hearken to your father; this one begot you, and do not despise your mother when she has grown old.
Buy truth and do not sell; [also] wisdom, discipline, and understanding.
The father of a righteous son will rejoice greatly, and he who begets a wise son will have joy with him.
May your father and mother rejoice, and may she who bore you have joy.
My son, give me your heart, and let your eyes keep my ways.
For a harlot is like a deep ditch and a foreign woman like a narrow well.
She, too, will suddenly lurk, and she will increase the faithless among men.
Who cries, "Woe!" Who, "Alas!" He who has quarrels. He who talks too much. Who has wounds without cause? Who has bloodshot eyes?
Those who sit late over wine, those who come to search for mixed wine.
Do not look at wine when it is red; when he puts his eye on the cup, it goes smoothly.
Ultimately, it will bite like a serpent, and sting like a viper.
Your eyes will see strange women, and your heart will speak confusedly.
And you shall be like one lying in the midst of the sea and like one lying at the top of a mast.
"They struck me but I did not become ill; they beat me but I did not know it. When will I awaken? I will continue; I will seek it again."
Do not envy men of evil; do not desire to be with them;
for their heart thinks of plunder, and their lips speak of wrongdoing.
A house is built with wisdom, and it is established with understanding.
With knowledge, the rooms are filled with all riches, precious and pleasant.
A wise man is with strength, and a man of knowledge maintains strength.
For you shall wage war for yourself with strategies, and the victory results from the superiority of the counselor.
Wisdom is as pearls to the fool; in the gate he will not open his mouth.
He who plots to do evil is called a man of wicked designs.
The counsel of folly is sin, and what makes man an abomination is scorn.
If you have become lax, on a day of trouble your strength will be weak indeed.
If you refrain from rescuing those taken to death and those on the verge of being slain
will you say, "Behold, we did not know this"? Is it not so that He Who counts hearts understands, and He Who guards your soul knows, and He will requite a man according to his deed?
Eat honey, my son, for it is good, and the honeycomb is sweet to your palate.
So too, know wisdom for your soul; if you have found it, you will have a future and your hope will not be cut off.
Wicked man, do not lurk by the dwelling of a righteous man; do not plunder his resting place.
For a righteous man can fall seven times and rise, but the wicked shall stumble upon evil.
When your enemy falls, do not rejoice, and when he stumbles, let your heart not exult,
lest the Lord see and be displeased, and turn His wrath away from him.
Do not compete with evildoers; do not envy the wicked
for there will be no future for an evil one; the lamp of the wicked will flicker.
My son, fear the Lord and the king; do not mingle with dualists.
For suddenly their misfortune will rise, and the ruin of both of them who knows?
These too are for the wise; To have respect [for persons] in judgment is not good.
He who says to a wicked man, "You are righteous"-peoples will curse him; nations will be wroth with him.
But for those who reprove it will be pleasant, and a good blessing shall come upon them.
Lips should kiss him who gives a right answer.
Prepare your work outside and make it fit in the field for yourself; afterwards you shall build your house.
Do not be a witness without cause for your friend, that you should be enticed with your lips.
Do not say, "As he did to me, so will I do to him; I will repay the man according to his deed."
By the fields of a lazy man, I passed and by the vineyard of a man without sense.
And behold, thistles had grown all over it; nettles had covered its surface, and its stone fence had been torn down.
And I, myself, saw; I applied my heart; I saw and learned a lesson.
Little sleep, little slumber, little clasping of the hands to lie down.
Then your poverty will come strolling and your wants like an armed man.
These too are Solomon's proverbs, which the men of Hezekiah, king of Judah, maintained.
The honor of God is to conceal a matter, whereas the honor of kings is to search out a matter.
The heaven for height, the earth for depth, and the honor of kings are unsearchable.
Remove dross from silver, and a vessel emerges for the refiner.
Remove the wicked man before the king, and his throne will be established with righteousness.
Do not glorify yourself before a king, and do not stand in the place of great men;
for it is better that he say to you, "Come up here," than to humble you before a prince, as your eyes have seen.
Do not go out quickly to quarrel lest [you will not know] what you will do at its end, when your friend puts you to shame.
Have your quarrel with your friend, but do not divulge another's secret
lest one who hears embarrass you, and your slander cannot be taken back.
Like golden apples on silverplated vessels, is a word spoken with proper basis.
Like a golden earring and jewelry of finest gold, is a wise man giving reproof to an ear that listens.
Like the cold of snow on the day of harvest, is an emissary faithful to his sender, who refreshes his master's soul.
Clouds and wind, but no rain-so is a man who boasts with a false gift.
The Ruler is won over with slowness to anger, and a gentle tongue will break a bone.
If you have found honey, eat enough for you, lest you become sated with it and vomit it.
Visit your neighbor sparingly, lest he become sated with you and hate you.
A man who testifies falsely against his friend is like a club, a sword, and a sharpened arrow.
Like a broken tooth and an unsteady leg is trust in a traitor on a day of trouble.
A worn-out garment on a cold day is like vinegar on chalk, and so is one who sings songs to a broken heart.
If your enemy is hungry, feed him bread, and if he is thirsty, give him water to drink;
for you will be scooping coals on his head, and the Lord will reward you.
As the north wind begets rain, so a backbiting tongue [begets] an angry countenance.
It is better to sit on the corner of a roof than a quarrelsome wife and a house of companionship.
As cold water to a faint soul, so is good news from a distant country.
A righteous man slipping before a wicked man is like a muddied spring and a ruined fountain.
Eating honey to excess is not good, but fathoming their honor is honor.
Like a broken city without a wall, so is a man whose spirit is unrestrained.
Like snow in the summer and like rain at harvest, so is honor unbefitting for a fool.
Like a wandering sparrow and like a flying swallow, so will a vain curse come home.
A whip is for the horse, a bridle is for the donkey, and a rod is for the body of fools.
Do not answer a fool according to his folly lest even you become like him.
Answer a fool according to his folly lest he be wise in his sight.
He who sends a message by the hand of a fool wears out legs and "drinks violence."
The thighs seem raised to a lame man, and [that is] a parable in the mouth of fools.
He who gives honor to a fool is as binding a stone in a slingshot.
A thorn came up in a drunkard's hand and a parable in the mouth of fools.
The Master created all, and He hires a fool, and He hires transients.
As a dog returns to his vomit, so does a fool repeat his folly.
If you see a man who is wise in his own eyes, there is more hope for a fool than for him.
The lazy man says, "There is a middle-sized lion on the road, a mature lion is between the streets."
As a door turns on its hinge so does a lazy man on his bed.
The lazy man buries his hand in the cauldron; it wearies him to bring it back to his mouth.
A lazy man in his own eyes is wiser than seven men who give advice.
A passerby who becomes embroiled in a quarrel that is not his is like one who grabs a dog by its ears.
Like one who wearies himself shooting firebrands, arrows, and death,
so is a man who deceives his friend and says, "Am I not joking?"
Just as without wood, the fire goes out, so without a grumbler the quarrel quiets down.
As charcoal is for coals and wood is for fire, so is a quarrelsome man for kindling strife.
Words of a grumbler are as though waging battle, and they penetrate the innermost parts of the body.
Burning lips and a wicked heart are like silver dross overlaid on earthenware.
An enemy dissembles with his lips and within him he places deceit.
When he entreats with his voice, do not believe him, for there are seven abominations in his heart.
When the hatred is covered with darkness, his evil will be revealed in public.
He who digs a pit will fall into it, and he who rolls a stone-it will return to him.
[He who has] a false tongue hates those crushed under him, and a smooth mouth effects rejection.
Do not boast for tomorrow, for you do not know what the day will bear.
May a stranger praise you and not your mouth, an alien and not your lips.
The weight of a stone and the burden of sand-the anger of a fool is heavier than both.
Cruelty of wrath, and destruction of anger, but who can stand up before jealousy?
Open rebuke is better than concealed love.
Wounds of a lover are faithful, whereas kisses of an enemy are burdensome.
A sated soul tramples honeycomb, but to a hungry soul all bitter is sweet.
As a bird wandering from its nest, so is a man wandering from his place.
Oil and incense make the heart rejoice, and the sweet words of his friend more than one's own counsel.
Do not forsake your friend and your father's friend, and do not enter your brother's house on the day of your misfortune; a close neighbor is better than a distant brother.
Be wise, my son, and cause my heart to rejoice, that I may answer him who taunts me.
A cunning man saw harm and hid, but fools passed and were punished.
Take his garment because he stood surety for a stranger, and hold him in pledge for an alien woman.
He who blesses his friend in a loud voice early every morning, it shall be considered a curse for him.
A constant dripping on a rainstormy day, and a quarrelsome woman, are alike.
He who guards her guards the wind, and he calls "the oil of his right hand."
Iron sharpens iron, and a man sharpens the countenance of his friend.
He who guards a fig-tree shall eat its fruit, and he who guards his master shall be honored.
As in water, face answers to face, so is the heart of a man to a man.
The grave and Gehinnom will not be sated, and the eyes of man will not be sated.
The refining pot is for silver and the furnace for gold, and a man according to his praise.
If you crush the fool in a mortar among grain with a pestle, his folly will not leave him.
Know well the condition of your flocks; give your attention to the herds.
For riches are not forever, neither is a crown for generations.
When the hay is carried away and the grass is visible, and the grasses of the mountains have been gathered,
there will be lambs for your clothing, and he-goats are the worth of the field;
and enough goat milk for your food, for the food of your household, and sustenance for your maidens.
The wicked flee without a pursuer, but the righteous are as trusting as a young lion.
Because of the sin of a land, its princes are many, but because of an understanding, knowledgeable man, so will [its retribution] be delayed.
A poor man who oppresses the poor is like a flooding rain that leaves no food.
Those who forsake the Torah praise the wicked, but those who keep the Torah contend with them.
Men of evil do not understand judgment, but those who seek the Lord understand everything.
A poor man who walks innocently is better than one of perverse ways who is rich.
He who keeps the Torah is the son of an understanding man, but he who befriends gluttons puts his father to shame.
He who increases his riches with usury and interest gathers it for him who is gracious to the poor.
He who turns his ear away from hearing the Torah-even his prayer is an abomination.
He who misleads the upright in an evil way will fall into his own pit, but the innocent will inherit goodness.
A rich man is wise in his own eyes, but a discerning poor man will search him out.
When the righteous rejoice, there is much glory, but when the wicked rise up, a person will be searched out.
He who conceals his sins will not succeed, but he who confesses and abandons [them] will obtain mercy.
Fortunate is the man who is always afraid, but he who hardens his heart will fall into evil.
A wicked man ruling over a poor people is like a roaring lion and a growling bear.
A ruler who lacks understanding is a great oppressor, for he who hates unlawful gain will live long.
A man who is guilty of robbing one's lifeblood will flee to the pit, but no one will support him.
He who walks innocently will be saved, but he who is perverse in his way will fall in one.
He who tills his soil will be sated with bread, but he who pursues vain things will be sated with poverty.
A trustworthy man will have many blessings, but he who hastens to become rich will not go unpunished.
To be partial is not good, but for a piece of bread a man will sin.
He who hastens to [acquire] wealth is a man with an evil eye, and he does not know that want will come upon him.
He who admonishes man after Me, will find more favor than he who speaks with flattery.
He who robs his father or his mother and says, "This is not a sin," is the companion of a destroyer.
A greedy man stirs up quarrels, but he who puts his trust in the Lord will be greatly gratified.
He who trusts his heart is a fool, but he who goes with wisdom will escape.
He who gives to a poor man will suffer no want, but he who hides his eyes will have many curses.
When the wicked rise up, people hide; but when they perish, the righteous increase.
A man who requires reproof but stiffens his nape, will suddenly be broken without cure.
When the righteous become great, the people rejoice, but when a wicked man rules, the people sigh.
A man who loves wisdom makes his father happy, but one who keeps company with harlots wastes his wealth.
A king establishes the country with justice, but a haughty man tears it down.
A man who flatters his friend spreads out a net for his feet.
When a wicked man sins, there is a snare, and a righteous man sings and rejoices.
A righteous man knows the judgment of the poor; a wicked man does not put his mind to knowing it.
Scornful men inflame a city, but the wise turn away wrath.
When a wise man contends with a foolish man, whether he is angry or he laughs, he will have no contentment.
Murderous men hate the innocent, but the upright seek his soul.
A fool lets out all his wind, but afterwards a wise man will quiet it.
A ruler who hearkens to false words-all his servants are wicked.
A poor man and a man of deep thoughts were visited upon; the Lord enlightens the eyes of both of them.
A king who judges the poor justly-his throne will be established forever.
A rod and reproof give wisdom, but a child left free brings shame to his mother.
When the wicked attain greatness, transgression increases, and the righteous will see their downfall.
Chastise your son and he will give you rest, and he will grant pleasures to your soul.
Without vision the people become unrestrained, but he who keeps the Torah is fortunate.
A slave cannot be chastised with words, because he will understand, but without response.
If you see a man hasty with his words, there is more hope for a fool than for him.
If one pampers his slave from childhood, he will ultimately be a ruler.
A quick-tempered man stirs up strife, and a wrathful man abounds in transgression.
A man's haughtiness will humble him, but one of humble spirit will grasp honor.
He who shares with a thief hates his soul; he hears an oath but does not testify.
A snare brings terror to a person, but he who trusts in the Lord will be safeguarded.
Many seek the countenance of a ruler, but the judgment of a person is from the Lord.
An unjust man is an abomination to the righteous, and a person whose way is straight is an abomination to a wicked man.
The words of Agur, the son of Jakeh, the prophecy; the words of the man concerning, "God is with me; yea, God is with me, and I will be able."
For I am more boorish than any man, neither do I have man's understanding.
Neither have I learned wisdom, nor do I know the knowledge of the holy ones.

Who ascended to heaven and descended? Who gathered wind in his fists? Who wrapped the waters in a garment? Who established all the ends of the earth? What is his name and what is the name of his son, if you know?
Every word of God is refined; He is a shield for all who take refuge in Him.
Do not add to His words, lest He prove to you, and you be found a liar.
I ask two [things] of You; do not withhold them from me before I die.
Distance falsehood and the lying word from me; give me neither poverty nor wealth; provide me my allotted bread,
lest I become sated and deny, and I say, "Who is the Lord?" And lest I become impoverished and steal, and take hold of the name of my God.
Do not inform on a slave to his master, lest he curse you, and you be found guilty.
A generation that curses its father and does not bless its mother.
A generation that is pure in its eyes, but is not cleansed of its filth.
A generation-how lofty are its eyes! And its eyelids are raised.
A generation whose teeth are [like] swords, and its molars are [like] knives, to devour the poor of the land and the needy of men.
The leech has two daughters, "Give" and "Give." There are three that are not sated, and four that do not say, "Enough!"
The grave, the confined womb, and the earth, which is not sated with water, and fire, which does not say, "Enough!"
The eye that mocks the father and despises the mother's wrinkles-may the ravens of the valley pick it out, and the young eagles devour it.
There are three things that are concealed from me, and four that I do not know;
The way of the eagle in the heavens, the way of a serpent on a rock, the way of a ship in the heart of the sea, and the way of a man with a young woman.
So is the way of an adulterous woman; she eats and wipes her mouth, and she says, "I have committed no sin."
Under three things the earth quakes, and under four it cannot endure;
Under a slave who rules and a wretch who is sated with food;
under a hated woman who is married, and a maidservant who inherits her mistress.
There are four small creatures on the earth, yet they are exceedingly wise;
The ants are a people not strong, yet they prepare their food in summer.
The hyraxes are a people not strong, yet they make their home in the rock.
The locusts have no king, yet they all go out in a troop.
The spider grasps with [her] hands, and she is in a king's palaces.
Three are outstanding in their step, and four are outstanding in their walk;
The lion is the mightiest of the beasts, who is undaunted by anyone.
The greyhound and the he-goat, and the king against whom no one dares to rise up.
If you have been put to shame, you will be in your ascendency; and if you thought evil, put your hand to your mouth.
For pressing milk will give out butter, and pressing the nose will give out blood, and pressing anger will give out strife.
The words of Lemuel the king; a prophecy that his mother chastised him;
What, my son, and what, the son of my womb, and what, the son of my vows?
Do not give your strength to women, nor your ways to the pleasures of kings.
It is not for kings, Lemoel, it is not for kings to drink wine, neither is strong drink for rulers.
Lest he drink and forget what was made law, and change the judgment of all the impoverished.
Give strong drink to the one who is perishing and wine to those of bitter soul.
Let him drink and forget his poverty, and let him remember his misery no more.
Open your mouth for the dumb, to the cause of all whose help has passed.
Open your mouth, judge justly and plead the cause of the poor and the needy.
A woman of valor who can find, for her price is beyond pearls.
Her husband relies on her, and he will lack no gain.
She requites him with good and not with evil all the days of her life.
She seeks wool and flax, and she works it with the will of her hands.
She is like the merchant ships, she brings her food from afar.
She rises when it is still night; she gives food to her household and an allotted share to her maidens.
She contemplates a field and purchases it; from the fruit of her hands she plants a vineyard.
She girds her loins with vigor and strengthens her arms.
[When] she advises that her merchandise is good her lamp does not go out at night.
She stretches forth her hands onto the distaff, and her hands support the spindle.
She spreads out her hand to the poor man, and she stretches her hands out to the needy.
She fears not for her household for snow, for all her household are dressed in crimson.
She makes beautiful bedspreads for herself; fine linen and purple wool are her raiment.
Her husband is known in the gates, when he sits with the elders of the land.
She makes a cloak and sells it, and she gives a belt to the trafficker.
Strength and beauty are her raiment, and she laughs at the last day.
She opens her mouth with wisdom, and instruction of kindness is on her tongue.
She supervises the ways of her household and does not eat bread of idleness.
Her children rise and call her fortunate; [also] her husband, and praises her.
"Many women have acquired wealth, but you surpass them all."
Charm is false and beauty is futile; a God-fearing woman is to be praised.
Give her of the fruit of her hands, and her deeds will praise her in the gates.
